posts.post_content: All you people who are complaining about its "drawback" are wrong. Think of it like this instead: Turn 8, play Terastodon, destroy three of your lands. Now you have a 9/9 and three 3/3s - you've just put 18 points of damage on the board and gained serious creature advantage. Plus, if you absolutely *must* kill [Jace, the Mind Sculptor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jace, the Mind Sculptor) or something, you can. This is a strong, well-designed card.
posts.html:
All you people who are complaining about its "drawback" are wrong. Think of it like this instead: Turn 8, play Terastodon, destroy three of your lands. Now you have a 9/9 and three 3/3s - you've just put 18 points of damage on the board and gained serious creature advantage. Plus, if you absolutely must kill Jace, the Mind Sculptor or something, you can. This is a strong, well-designed card.

Posted By: DlCK (1/29/2010 8:24:17 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Terastadon + fire spout to just blow things up and then remove the tokens, but the great thing about it is utility, you can destroy three of your own lands to get a lot of extra creatures. Takes care of planeswalkers as well, being able to mix and match any noncreature permanents. Can also destroy enchantments like hatching plans. It's arguably both better and worse than woodfall primus, who comes with trample and without the seeming drawback, but then isn't quite as flexible.
posts.html:
Terastadon + fire spout to just blow things up and then remove the tokens, but the great thing about it is utility, you can destroy three of your own lands to get a lot of extra creatures. Takes care of planeswalkers as well, being able to mix and match any noncreature permanents. Can also destroy enchantments like hatching plans. It's arguably both better and worse than woodfall primus, who comes with trample and without the seeming drawback, but then isn't quite as flexible.

posts.post_content:
8 CMC for a possible 9/9, 3/3, 3/3, 3/3, and destroy 3 target non-creature permanents?!? Too damn cheap!!  
Surprised Worldwake didn't make this a Mythic Rare since it's stupidly strong.   
MTG is aiming to annoy the hell out of old school players.  
  
On the other hand, I played a MP game where a teammate had this in his hand. I told him I was gonna play [Armageddon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Armageddon) so then he just destroyed his own lands since they were gonna get destroyed anyway. Good stuff.

Posted By: kotor (3/11/2010 2:21:17 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
The versatility in choosing what to blow up makes this card a gem.  
Screw your opponent out of a needed color, an artifact cornerstone, a planeswalker ready to ultimate, or just put 18 power on the board.  
  
The lack of trample, while extremely peculiar, is hardly a deal breaker.  
  
edit; I knew this reminded me of something.  
[Crush of Wurms](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crush of Wurms) is also 18 power divided up a bunch of ways.
